{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":2985559,"name":"khope","username":"khope","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/k/f6c823/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-01-06T16:08:54.290Z","cooked":"

Hello there, I‚Äôve been moved from being a programming mentor to the build mentor for this season due to previous build mentors retirement from the team. We‚Äôve historically used 80/20 along with the KOP Chassis. I want to try and migrate over to using VersaFrame system (on top of the KOP Chassis) this year to test it out the ‚Äúcan be built with basic tools‚Äù theory since our team lacks many advanced manufacturing capabilities and building experience (mentors and students). I plan to go ahead and pre-order some stock so that we have some on-hand once we enter our prototyping and building in a couple of weeks. I wanted to see if anyone had any general or specific recommendations on which stock sizes you‚Äôve found more beneficial to have on hand? Or any great resources to help us learn how to dream up the cool configurations we see on other robots? I saw this website in a thread today and plan to explore it for inspiration. Also if you‚Äôve made the same switchover at some point if you have any lessons learned, that would be great to hear too.

Thanks in advance!

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":42,"updated_at":"2022-01-06T16:08:54.290Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":81,"reads":330,"readers_count":329,"score":501.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":398766,"topic_slug":"switching-over-to-versaframe-recommendations","display_username":"khope","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.projectb.net.au/resources/robot-mechanisms/","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"The Unofficial FRC Mechanism Encyclopedia ‚Äì Project Bucephalus","clicks":19}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":31620,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"4779 - The RoboSapiens"},"post_url":"/t/switching-over-to-versaframe-recommendations/398766/1","custom_user_title":"4779 - The RoboSapiens","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":2985566,"name":"Sean Lavery","username":"Lil_Lavery","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/lil_lavery/{size}/65226_2.png","created_at":"2022-01-06T16:19:01.989Z","cooked":"

Some quick tips off the top of my head:

  • Use 3/16 rivets rather than 5/32. This will require drilling the holes to be slightly larger, but that can easily be done with a cordless drill

*Buy more gussets than you think you‚Äôll need. You‚Äôll burn thru t-shaped and/or plus-shaped gussets quickly.

*Dont be afraid to drill new holes on the ‚Äúsolid‚Äù faces when you need to. Especially useful when making angled cuts.

*Get comfortable with a workflow that lets you cut the segments to length quickly and accurately. We use a miter saw, but a bandsaw can work just as well. Hack saws or reciprocating saws can get the job done in a pinch, but shouldn‚Äôt be your go-to.

*Get comfortable match-drilling, and your options for mounting components and gussets will expand.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":42,"updated_at":"2022-01-06T16:59:10.251Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":319,"readers_count":318,"score":128.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":398766,"topic_slug":"switching-over-to-versaframe-recommendations","display_username":"Sean Lavery","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":2514,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"FRC 1712"},"post_url":"/t/switching-over-to-versaframe-recommendations/398766/2","custom_user_title":"FRC 1712","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2985567,"name":"tjwolter - Mentor, supply clerk and chief janitor Team 5826","username":"tjwolter","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tjwolter/{size}/131306_2.png","created_at":"2022-01-06T16:19:30.700Z","cooked":"

Same boat. We moved from a sponsor‚Äôs facility, which was basically Robot Disneyland, into a school setting with minimal access to goodies. We are going to take on our first build using tube and versaframe. Good Lord our last competition machine was entirely CAD designed, laser cut and welded together from about 40 pieces.

bot461√ó508 129 KB

You‚Äôll need to be able to mark, drill and cut accurately and get good quickly with rivets. Having to work mostly with a miter saw we have had competitions to see who can cut closest to specs. One of our kids has a talent for quality control and gets the micrometer out to judge. We‚Äôve also practices with rivets 3/16 and 1/4 as well as rivnuts which look useful for attaching upper works to drive base. We‚Äôve used little 80/20 ‚Äúfeet‚Äù in the past with success.

If you are long on 80/20 parts you likely have some sturdy 1/4 based brackets around. These are pretty handy for tube rivet frame.

In general 1 by 2 and 1 by 1 are the most useful. We have a mix of versaframe and generic tube, but we do have some decent drill jigs the kids have made. 1/16th thickness should suffice although there might be call for the occasional 1/8 in a real load bearing situation?

Others here know much more but thought I chime in as we are in a similar situation. Feel free to PM if more detailed questions.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":42,"updated_at":"2022-01-06T16:19:30.700Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":304,"readers_count":303,"score":90.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":398766,"topic_slug":"switching-over-to-versaframe-recommendations","display_username":"tjwolter - Mentor, supply clerk and chief janitor Team 5826","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/uploads/default/original/3X/7/0/70cbe5a53656ba82931e4a2c5ef28fa4b5dd0ec6.jpeg","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":28254,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/switching-over-to-versaframe-recommendations/398766/3","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2985581,"name":"Lexeo","username":"Lexeo","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/lexeo/{size}/160041_2.png","created_at":"2022-01-06T16:39:13.387Z","cooked":"

We are also looking to implement VersaFrame in to our build process this season. We have tended to build with a plate and standoff style, but are thinking that maybe this could add some more possibilities.

With teams that use it, what are their thoughts on 3D printed drilling jigs. Given the hole pattern, it seems like you could get pretty good alignment with a 3D printed jig that bolts to the holes for alignment and uses some drill bushings. Ive also imagined some 3D printed miter saw jigs to ensure that your cuts are where you want them.

Thoughts?

Imagining things like this

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":42,"updated_at":"2022-01-06T17:31:03.880Z","reply_count":3,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":276,"readers_count":275,"score":85.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":398766,"topic_slug":"switching-over-to-versaframe-recommendations","display_username":"Lexeo","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.thethriftybot.com/bearings/Thrifty-Press-Fit-Drill-Bushings-p164961408","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":9}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":25373,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Team 4272 Lead Mentor and Head Robot Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/switching-over-to-versaframe-recommendations/398766/4","custom_user_title":"Team 4272 Lead Mentor and Head Robot Mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2985582,"name":"Brian Wagg","username":"cad321","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/c57346/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-01-06T16:39:49.113Z","cooked":"
tjwolter:

gets the micrometer out to judge

Dear lord, how big is your micrometer? Or how small are the parts you are cutting for these mini competitions?

I say this as most highschool shops I‚Äôve been in locally have pretty much only 1" mic‚Äôs, and on rare occasion a random 2" or 3" one.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":42,"updated_at":"2022-01-06T16:39:49.113Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":6,"reads":259,"readers_count":258,"score":86.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":398766,"topic_slug":"switching-over-to-versaframe-recommendations","display_username":"Brian Wagg","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.grainger.ca/en/product/MICROMETER-16-20IN/p/MTT104-153","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":12}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":19532,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Brian Wagg"},"post_url":"/t/switching-over-to-versaframe-recommendations/398766/5","custom_user_title":"Brian Wagg","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2985594,"name":"tjwolter - Mentor, supply clerk and chief janitor Team 5826","username":"tjwolter","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tjwolter/{size}/131306_2.png","created_at":"2022-01-06T16:54:46.984Z","cooked":"

In a discussion on precision I should be more precise. I of course meant digital caliper. You can cut a nice 4 inch long piece and put a couple holes in the right place. I think our current build lead has the title. Something like 5/1000‚Äôs off.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":42,"updated_at":"2022-01-06T16:54:46.984Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":253,"readers_count":252,"score":80.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":398766,"topic_slug":"switching-over-to-versaframe-recommendations","display_username":"tjwolter - Mentor, supply clerk and chief janitor Team 5826","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":19532,"username":"cad321","name":"Brian Wagg","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/c57346/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":28254,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/switching-over-to-versaframe-recommendations/398766/6","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2985598,"name":"Gus Michel II","username":"GeeTwo","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/geetwo/{size}/120962_2.png","created_at":"2022-01-06T16:59:59.443Z","cooked":"

I‚Äôve mentored several robots featuring VF on top of the AM14U*. The most effective way seems to be to get a piece of 1x1 channel, and drill the holes in the center face out to 3/16, and rivet or bolt them to the top of the AM14U. Then, use regular VF gussets on the side faces of the channel as a foundation to work up.
Here‚Äôs an example:

pic: Wolfgang - 3946's STEAMworks robot CD-Media: Photos
[da41cdaaa7855816d8d8dc49224c63db_l.jpg] Wolfang, 3946‚Äôs robot for STEAMworks. Features pop-up gear slide extension, active gear hanger powered by [link=‚Äúpaper: The Scoosh - a novel approach to linear motion - CD-Media: Papers - Chief Delphi‚Äù]the scoosh[/link], and a climbing winch that tucks under the gear slide and drops out to grab the rope.

A neat trick used here is that a 7.5"-13"-15" triangle is a really good approximation to a 30¬∞-60¬∞-90¬∞ right triangle.

The 2019 robot used that 6"-6"-8.5" is really close to 45¬∞-45¬∞-90¬∞.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":42,"updated_at":"2022-01-06T17:05:56.373Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":248,"readers_count":247,"score":89.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":398766,"topic_slug":"switching-over-to-versaframe-recommendations","display_username":"Gus Michel II","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/pic-wolfgang-3946s-steamworks-robot/183459","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"pic: Wolfgang - 3946's STEAMworks robot","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":22335,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Somebody Else ‚¨õüü´üü•üüßüü®üü©üü¶üü™‚ñí‚ñí‚¨ú "},"post_url":"/t/switching-over-to-versaframe-recommendations/398766/7","custom_user_title":"Somebody Else ‚¨õüü´üü•üüßüü®üü©üü¶üü™‚ñí‚ñí‚¨ú ","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2985603,"name":"khope","username":"khope","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/k/f6c823/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-01-06T17:13:08.441Z","cooked":"

Thanks for the feedback. Is it safe to assume that the recommendation for using 3/16 rivets as opposed to the 3/32 ones due to increased strength? Or is there some other benefit?

Kevin

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":42,"updated_at":"2022-01-06T17:13:08.441Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":226,"readers_count":225,"score":55.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":398766,"topic_slug":"switching-over-to-versaframe-recommendations","display_username":"khope","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":2514,"username":"Lil_Lavery","name":"Sean Lavery","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/lil_lavery/{size}/65226_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":31620,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"4779 - The RoboSapiens"},"post_url":"/t/switching-over-to-versaframe-recommendations/398766/8","custom_user_title":"4779 - The RoboSapiens","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2985604,"name":"Tom Line","username":"Tom_Line","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tom_line/{size}/236809_2.png","created_at":"2022-01-06T17:13:40.389Z","cooked":"

I do have a couple suggestions.

First - The Thrifty Bot sells some gussets similar to Vex at about 15-20% discount. Second, do you really need to use tubes with pre-drilled holes? You can even use a gusset to make sure you holes are centered and spaced correctly. The pre drilled holes can come in handy at times, but they also come with a bit of a price premium.

Vex:
2 90 degree versa gussets - $5.99, so 5.99 * 4 = $24
The Thrifty Bot:
8 90 degree thrifty gussets - $19.99

Vex:
1 1"x1"x59" (.4 wall) versa tube - $25
From online metals:
1 1"x1"x60" (.625) - $13.82

Shipping TBD of course. So ask yourself if you really need those pre-drilled holes in the tubes.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":42,"updated_at":"2022-01-06T17:13:40.389Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":219,"readers_count":218,"score":128.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":398766,"topic_slug":"switching-over-to-versaframe-recommendations","display_username":"Tom Line","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":7841,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Team 1498"},"post_url":"/t/switching-over-to-versaframe-recommendations/398766/9","custom_user_title":"Team 1498","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":5}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2985607,"name":"Gus Michel II","username":"GeeTwo","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/geetwo/{size}/120962_2.png","created_at":"2022-01-06T17:18:22.618Z","cooked":"
khope:

Thanks for the feedback. Is it safe to assume that the recommendation for using 3/16 rivets as opposed to the 3/32 ones due to increased strength? Or is there some other benefit?

The holes in the top of the AM14U series are for 10 screws or 3/16" rivets. VF holes are for 5/32" rivets. My preference is not to bore them out unless the strength seems inadequate. I prefer to mount the gussets using existing holes, then match drill the remaining gusset holes into the tube and rivet these.

Though an advantage of 3/16" is that they‚Äôre easier to find at the hardware store or home center.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":42,"updated_at":"2022-01-06T17:18:22.618Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":207,"readers_count":206,"score":41.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":398766,"topic_slug":"switching-over-to-versaframe-recommendations","display_username":"Gus Michel II","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"/tag/10","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":22335,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Somebody Else ‚¨õüü´üü•üüßüü®üü©üü¶üü™‚ñí‚ñí‚¨ú "},"post_url":"/t/switching-over-to-versaframe-recommendations/398766/10","custom_user_title":"Somebody Else ‚¨õüü´üü•üüßüü®üü©üü¶üü™‚ñí‚ñí‚¨ú ","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2985608,"name":"khope","username":"khope","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/k/f6c823/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-01-06T17:18:24.590Z","cooked":"

Thanks for the tips. We are primarily in the same boat. We‚Äôve lost our build space in a machine shop and are now going back to a ‚Äúshop‚Äù at the school which is primarily just an insulated and heated detached garage. I‚Äôve picked up a small bandsaw for us to use and we have a MitreSaw with a metal cutting blade installed. I‚Äôm planning on also picking up a benchtop drill press for the shop but haven‚Äôt pulled the trigger yet. Any recommendations on a decent one or any other ‚Äúgotta-have-it‚Äù tools when working with VersaFrame? We also have a couple of cordless drills.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":42,"updated_at":"2022-01-06T17:18:24.590Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":201,"readers_count":200,"score":50.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":398766,"topic_slug":"switching-over-to-versaframe-recommendations","display_username":"khope","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":28254,"username":"tjwolter","name":"tjwolter - Mentor, supply clerk and chief janitor Team 5826","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tjwolter/{size}/131306_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":31620,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"4779 - The RoboSapiens"},"post_url":"/t/switching-over-to-versaframe-recommendations/398766/11","custom_user_title":"4779 - The RoboSapiens","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2985610,"name":"Tom Line","username":"Tom_Line","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tom_line/{size}/236809_2.png","created_at":"2022-01-06T17:19:59.381Z","cooked":"

I don‚Äôt know your funding level, but we‚Äôve found a pneumatic rivet gun to extremely useful. Barring that, some teams have had luck with the electric-drill driven name brand riveters‚Ä¶ but those seem to wear out quickly.

A pneumatic rivet gun (name brand like arrow from amazon) + compressor (el-cheapo 5 or 8 gallon from somewhere like harbor fright) end up running around $200 total.

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":42,"updated_at":"2022-01-06T17:25:29.702Z","reply_count":3,"reply_to_post_number":11,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":201,"readers_count":200,"score":55.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":398766,"topic_slug":"switching-over-to-versaframe-recommendations","display_username":"Tom Line","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":31620,"username":"khope","name":"khope","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/k/f6c823/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":7841,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Team 1498"},"post_url":"/t/switching-over-to-versaframe-recommendations/398766/12","custom_user_title":"Team 1498","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2985614,"name":"FrankJ","username":"FrankJ","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/frankj/{size}/5392_2.png","created_at":"2022-01-06T17:31:44.043Z","cooked":"

With Versa pay close attention on how the pre-drilled holes line up with ends especially when working in pairs and symmetry is important. Lengths work out best in inches with 1/2" increments. Sorry rest of the world.

","post_number":13,"post_type":1,"posts_count":42,"updated_at":"2022-01-06T17:31:44.043Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":195,"readers_count":194,"score":89.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":398766,"topic_slug":"switching-over-to-versaframe-recommendations","display_username":"FrankJ","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":15944,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2974 Robot Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/switching-over-to-versaframe-recommendations/398766/13","custom_user_title":"2974 Robot Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2985615,"name":"Sean Lavery","username":"Lil_Lavery","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/lil_lavery/{size}/65226_2.png","created_at":"2022-01-06T17:34:17.653Z","cooked":"

Yes, the primary advantage of the 3/16 rivet to the 5/32 is the increased strength. We‚Äôve found that 5/32 Al mandrel rivets were prone to eventually coming loose/failing over the course of an FRC season (particularly in high shock load games like 2016). After we switched to 3/16, this became far less of an issue.

","post_number":14,"post_type":1,"posts_count":42,"updated_at":"2022-01-06T17:34:17.653Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":188,"readers_count":187,"score":52.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":398766,"topic_slug":"switching-over-to-versaframe-recommendations","display_username":"Sean Lavery","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":31620,"username":"khope","name":"khope","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/k/f6c823/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":2514,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"FRC 1712"},"post_url":"/t/switching-over-to-versaframe-recommendations/398766/14","custom_user_title":"FRC 1712","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2985619,"name":"tjwolter - Mentor, supply clerk and chief janitor Team 5826","username":"tjwolter","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tjwolter/{size}/131306_2.png","created_at":"2022-01-06T17:42:01.482Z","cooked":"

As others have mentioned, versa frame is a mixed blessing. You can make holes in generic Al frame and in some cases make your life easier. To do that I suggest a couple of good spring load center punches (get two of all small important tools if affordable!) , some marker fluid, a really narrow marking stylus (blade of a box cutter seems to work), and of course measuring devices of your choice. We have a pretty green crew this season and have been playing around with stuff. Big fan of Thriftybot and second the nom on their brackets and such. We have some off site laser access so can make our own as well. We‚Äôve been prototyping with their clamp on bearing blocks. Likely others make them as well. You‚Äôll need something to put a hole through tube big enough for a hex shaft. Various options exist but a small metal cutting hole saw works for the patient. We had a pneumatic riveter but it gave us a bit of trouble. It‚Äôs now on the ‚Äúget around to it‚Äù shelf where it will likely stay a while. I mentioned 1/4 rivets a while back. Really overkill but I suspected you had 80/20 brackets from your prior builds. Sometimes a bit of overkill is ok.

","post_number":15,"post_type":1,"posts_count":42,"updated_at":"2022-01-06T17:42:01.482Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":11,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":185,"readers_count":184,"score":62.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":398766,"topic_slug":"switching-over-to-versaframe-recommendations","display_username":"tjwolter - Mentor, supply clerk and chief janitor Team 5826","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":31620,"username":"khope","name":"khope","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/k/f6c823/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":28254,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/switching-over-to-versaframe-recommendations/398766/15","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2985635,"name":"Brian Wagg","username":"cad321","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/c57346/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-01-06T17:58:52.678Z","cooked":"

Another +1 for a pneumatic rivet gun. If you truly do commit to rivets in a season, this will save you ample hours of time (downside is you don‚Äôt get to work on your forearms nearly as much ).

We‚Äôve also just picked up an electric Milwaukee rivet gun this year for use both at home and in the pits (compressors are very much frowned upon in the pits up here). I‚Äôve used these on past teams with great success!

If the budget is a problem, you can get a two-handed riveter pretty cheap! A couple of samples:

amazon.com

Amazon.com: Pop Rivet Gun with 200pcs Rivets,JiGiU Manual Rivet Gun Kit Heavy...

Buy Pop Rivet Gun with 200pcs Rivets,JiGiU Manual Rivet Gun Kit Heavy Duty Two Hands Riveter Hand Rivet Tool Labor Saving Include 5 Interchangeable Rivet Heads for Plastic Metal Leather Vehicle - JGU002: Riveters - Amazon.com ‚úì FREE DELIVERY possible...

Harbor Freight Tools

17-1/2 in. Hand Riveter with Collection Bottle

Heavy Duty 17-1/2" Hand Riveter With Collection Bottle

I bought 3946 one of the Harbor Freight ones in 2016 or 2017 to do 1/4" rivets. It was used so much (for other sizes as well) I bought them a second. Both were still in use as of the 2019 competition season (last time I connected with the team). I‚Äôve got one, too.

Do you do it every time you cut a piece of tube to length? I guess the days of me using my fat carpenter pencil are behind me

","post_number":19,"post_type":1,"posts_count":42,"updated_at":"2022-01-07T02:46:48.417Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":149,"readers_count":148,"score":54.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":398766,"topic_slug":"switching-over-to-versaframe-recommendations","display_username":"khope","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":22335,"username":"GeeTwo","name":"Gus Michel II","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/geetwo/{size}/120962_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":31620,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"4779 - The RoboSapiens"},"post_url":"/t/switching-over-to-versaframe-recommendations/398766/19","custom_user_title":"4779 - The RoboSapiens","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2985863,"name":"tjwolter - Mentor, supply clerk and chief janitor Team 5826","username":"tjwolter","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tjwolter/{size}/131306_2.png","created_at":"2022-01-07T02:51:07.064Z","cooked":"

Well, in the past and in the future we‚Äôll just fire up the CNC and put all the holes and cuts right where they should be. Doing it by hand for the time being means Old School. Careful measure. Dab of blue marker paint. Scribe carefully and in the case of drilling give it a good punch and use the laser cross hairs on the drill press to put the pilot hole spot on. Know how wide your saw blade is and adjust your measurements accordingly. ‚ÄúKerf‚Äù, your word for the day.

Seems primitive but basic metalworking is not something most kids get exposed to.

In parallel we are of course also ramping up our CAD efforts, doing more outreach to laser cutting firms in the community (frustrating issues with .dxl files from Fusion right now).

In retirement I‚Äôve actually gone back to Tech School and learned this stuff. Making a nice precise part by hand is very satisfying. But you have to also advance as your circumstances allow into CNC, lasers, high end 3D printing.

Best o‚Äô Luck. I‚Äôm not really a builder either. Retired ER doc.
